instructions: Open the C:\Program Files (x86)\Skype\Phone\ directory. Right-click Skype.exe . Select the Security tab and click Edit . Click ALL APPLICATION PACKAGES , and select the Write checkbox under Allow . Click OK .

Tap the Photos app to launch it. Go to the Albums tab, then tap Recently Deleted . The Recently Deleted photo album contains photos deleted in the last 30 days. It shows each photo and lists the number of days that remain until the iPhone deletes it. Tap Select , tap the photos you want to save, then tap Recover . Tap Recover Photo . Find the photo in the Camera Roll and other albums it was stored in before it was deleted.

Drsunil V October 4, 2013 at 6:34 pm Please note : This feature is available in Gmail Android Oron J September 27, 2013 at 4:16 pm Can you explain a bit more? Once you click on "Send", what do you want to happen? I know of no email program or service that will ordinarily say "are you sure you want to send this message" at this stage. There are programs, extensions etc which will check for specific potential errors (such as "you mentioned 'attachments' in your message, did you forget to send them") but that doesn't sound quite like what you are after. Drsunil V September 29, 2013 at 5:37 pm This feature is in mobile gmail app settings. But question is for web interface for desktop Oron J September 30, 2013 at 8:54 am Ah, this makes sense. On a mobile, it's easy to touch the send button by mistake, hence this safety feature. On a desktop, it's assumed that when you click a button you mean it, except for very specific situations (replacing a file, for example), which is why mail clients don't have this feature. If anyone knows of such a feature in GMail or indeed in mail clients, I'd also be very interested to hear about it!
